1996  /* Compute maximum sampling factors; check factor validity */
1997  m_max_h_samp_factor = 1;
1998  m_max_v_samp_factor = 1;
1999  for (var ci = 0; ci < m_num_components; ci++)
2000  {
2001  if (compInfo[ci].H_samp_factor <= 0
2002  || compInfo[ci].H_samp_factor > JpegConstants.MAX_SAMP_FACTOR
2003  || compInfo[ci].V_samp_factor <= 0
2004  || compInfo[ci].V_samp_factor > JpegConstants.MAX_SAMP_FACTOR)
2005  {
2006  ErrExit(JMessageCode.JERR_BAD_SAMPLING);
2007  }
2008 
2009  m_max_h_samp_factor = Math.Max(m_max_h_samp_factor, compInfo[ci].H_samp_factor);
2010  m_max_v_samp_factor = Math.Max(m_max_v_samp_factor, compInfo[ci].V_samp_factor);
2011  }
2012 
2013  /* Compute dimensions of components */
2014  for (var ci = 0; ci < m_num_components; ci++)
2015  {
2016  var compptr = compInfo[ci];
2017  /* Fill in the correct component_index value; don't rely on application */
2018  compptr.Component_index = ci;
2019 
2020  /* In selecting the actual DCT scaling for each component, we try to
2021  * scale down the chroma components via DCT scaling rather than downsampling.
2022  * This saves time if the downsampler gets to use 1:1 scaling.
2023  * Note this code adapts subsampling ratios which are powers of 2.
2024  */
2025  var ssize = 1;
2026  var upSampleSize = DoFancyDownsampling
2027  ? JpegConstants.DCTSIZE
2028  : JpegConstants.DCTSIZE / 2;
2029 
2030  while (min_DCT_h_scaled_size * ssize <= upSampleSize
2031  && (m_max_h_samp_factor % (compptr.H_samp_factor * ssize * 2)) == 0)
2032  {
2033  ssize *= 2;
2034  }
2035 
2036  compptr.DCT_h_scaled_size = min_DCT_h_scaled_size * ssize;
2037  ssize = 1;
2038  while (min_DCT_v_scaled_size * ssize <= upSampleSize
2039  && (m_max_v_samp_factor % (compptr.V_samp_factor * ssize * 2)) == 0)
2040  {
2041  ssize *= 2;
2042  }
2043 
2044  compptr.DCT_v_scaled_size = min_DCT_v_scaled_size * ssize;
2045 
2046  /* We don't support DCT ratios larger than 2. */
2047  if (compptr.DCT_h_scaled_size > compptr.DCT_v_scaled_size * 2)
2048  {
2049  compptr.DCT_h_scaled_size = compptr.DCT_v_scaled_size * 2;
2050  }
2051  else if (compptr.DCT_v_scaled_size > compptr.DCT_h_scaled_size * 2)
2052  {
2053  compptr.DCT_v_scaled_size = compptr.DCT_h_scaled_size * 2;
2054  }
2055 
2056  /* Size in DCT blocks */
2057  compptr.Width_in_blocks = (int)JpegUtils.jdiv_round_up(
2058  (long)jpeg_width * compptr.H_samp_factor, (long)m_max_h_samp_factor * BlockSize);
2059 
2060  compptr.height_in_blocks = (int)JpegUtils.jdiv_round_up(
2061  (long)jpeg_height * compptr.V_samp_factor, (long)m_max_v_samp_factor * BlockSize);
2062 
2063  /* Size in samples */
2064  compptr.downsampled_width = (int)JpegUtils.jdiv_round_up(
2065  (long)jpeg_width * compptr.H_samp_factor * compptr.DCT_h_scaled_size,
2066  (long)m_max_h_samp_factor * BlockSize);
2067 
2068  compptr.downsampled_height = (int)JpegUtils.jdiv_round_up(
2069  (long)jpeg_height * compptr.V_samp_factor * compptr.DCT_v_scaled_size,
2070  (long)m_max_v_samp_factor * BlockSize);
2071 
2072  /* Don't need quantization scale after DCT,
2073  * until color conversion says otherwise.
2074  */
2075  compptr.component_needed = false;
2076  }
2077 
2078  /* Compute number of fully interleaved MCU rows (number of times that
2079  * main controller will call coefficient controller).
2080  */
2081  m_total_iMCU_rows = (int)JpegUtils.jdiv_round_up(
2082  jpeg_height, (long)m_max_v_samp_factor * BlockSize);
2083  }

Master selection of compression modules. This is done once at the start of processing an image. We determine which modules will be used and give them appropriate initialization calls. This routine is in charge of selecting the modules to be executed and making an initialization call to each one.

◆ JpegAddQuantTable()

void BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.JpegAddQuantTable ( int  which_tbl,
int []  basic_table,
int  scale_factor,
bool  force_baseline 
)
inline

Allows an arbitrary quantization table to be created.

Parameters
which_tblIndicates which table slot to fill.
basic_tableAn array of 64 unsigned integers given in normal array order. These values are multiplied by scale_factor/100 and then clamped to the range 1..65535 (or to 1..255 if force_baseline is true).
The basic table should be given in JPEG zigzag order.
scale_factorMultiplier for values in basic_table.
force_baselineDefines range of values in basic_table. If true - 1..255, otherwise - 1..65535.

Compression parameter selection

721  else if (globalState != JpegState.CSTATE_WRCOEFS)
722  {
723  ErrExit(JMessageCode.JERR_BAD_STATE, (int)globalState);
724  }
725 
726  /* Perform any remaining passes */
727  while (!m_master.IsLastPass())
728  {
729  m_master.PrepareForPass();
730  for (iMCU_row = 0; iMCU_row < m_total_iMCU_rows; iMCU_row++)
731  {
732  if (prog is object)
733  {
734  prog.PassCounter = iMCU_row;
735  prog.PassLimit = m_total_iMCU_rows;
736  prog.Updated();
737  }
738 
739  /* We bypass the main controller and invoke coef controller directly;
740  * all work is being done from the coefficient buffer.
741  */
742  if (!m_coef.CompressData(null))
743  {
744  ErrExit(JMessageCode.JERR_CANT_SUSPEND);
745  }
746  }
747 
748  m_master.FinishPass();
749  }
750 
751  /* Write EOI, do final cleanup */
752  m_marker.WriteFileTrailer();
753  m_dest.TermDestination();
754 
755  /* We can use jpeg_abort to release memory and reset global_state */
756  JpegAbort();
757  }

static int BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.JpegQualityScaling ( int  quality)
inlinestatic

Converts a value on the IJG-recommended quality scale to a linear scaling percentage.

Parameters
qualityThe IJG-recommended quality scale. Should be 0 (terrible) to 100 (very good).
Returns
The linear scaling percentage.

Compression parameter selection

Definition at line 1279 of file JpegCompressStruct.cs.

1280  {
1281  /* Safety limit on quality factor. Convert 0 to 1 to avoid zero divide. */
1282  if (quality <= 0)
1283  {
1284  quality = 1;
1285  }
1286 
1287  if (quality > 100)
1288  {
1289  quality = 100;
1290  }
1291 
1292  /* The basic table is used as-is (scaling 100) for a quality of 50.
1293  * Qualities 50..100 are converted to scaling percentage 200 - 2*Q;
1294  * note that at Q=100 the scaling is 0, which will cause jpeg_add_quant_table
1295  * to make all the table entries 1 (hence, minimum quantization loss).
1296  * Qualities 1..50 are converted to scaling percentage 5000/Q.
1297  */
1298  return quality < 50 ? 5000 / quality : 200 - (quality * 2);
1299  }

Uses only the input image's color space (property JpegCompressStruct.In_color_space, which must already be set in JpegCompressStruct). Many applications will only need to use this routine and perhaps JpegCompressStruct.JpegSetQuality.

◆ JpegSetLinearQuality()

void BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.JpegSetLinearQuality ( int  scale_factor,
bool  force_baseline 
)
inline

Same as JpegSetQuality except that the generated tables are the sample tables given in the JPEG specification section K.1, multiplied by the specified scale factor.

Parameters
scale_factorThe scale_factor.
force_baselineIf true, then the quantization table entries are constrained to the range 1..255 for full JPEG baseline compatibility. In the current implementation, this only makes a difference for quality settings below 25, and it effectively prevents very small/low quality files from being generated. The IJG decoder is capable of reading the non-baseline files generated at low quality settings when force_baseline is false, but other decoders may not be.

Note that larger scale factors give lower quality. This entry point is useful for conforming to the Adobe PostScript DCT conventions, but we do not recommend linear scaling as a user-visible quality scale otherwise.

Compression parameter selection

◆ JpegSetQuality()

void BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.JpegSetQuality ( int  quality,
bool  force_baseline 
)
inline

Constructs JPEG quantization tables appropriate for the indicated quality setting.

Parameters
qualityThe quality value is expressed on the 0..100 scale recommended by IJG.
force_baselineIf true, then the quantization table entries are constrained to the range 1..255 for full JPEG baseline compatibility. In the current implementation, this only makes a difference for quality settings below 25, and it effectively prevents very small/low quality files from being generated. The IJG decoder is capable of reading the non-baseline files generated at low quality settings when force_baseline is false, but other decoders may not be.

Note that the exact mapping from quality values to tables may change in future IJG releases as more is learned about DCT quantization.

Compression parameter selection

◆ JpegSimpleProgression()

void BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.JpegSimpleProgression ( )
inline

Generates a default scan script for writing a progressive-JPEG file.

This is the recommended method of creating a progressive file, unless you want to make a custom scan sequence. You must ensure that the JPEG color space is set correctly before calling this routine.

Compression parameter selection

◆ JpegSuppressTables()

void BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.JpegSuppressTables ( bool  suppress)
inline

Forcibly suppress or un-suppress all quantization and Huffman tables.

Marks all currently defined tables as already written (if suppress) or not written (if !suppress). This will control whether they get emitted by a subsequent JpegCompressStruct.JpegStartCompression call.

This routine is exported for use by applications that want to produce abbreviated JPEG datastreams.

Parameters
suppressif set to true then suppress tables; otherwise unsuppress.

◆ JpegWriteMHeader()

void BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.JpegWriteMHeader ( int  marker,
int  datalen 
)
inline

Writes special marker's header.

Parameters
markerSpecial marker.
datalenLength of data associated with the marker.

After calling this method you need to call JpegCompressStruct.JpegWriteMByte exactly the number of times given in the length parameter.
This method lets you empty the output buffer partway through a marker, which might be important when using a suspending data destination module. In any case, if you are using a suspending destination, you should flush its buffer after inserting any special markers.

See also
JpegCompressStruct.JpegWriteMByte, JpegCompressStruct.JpegWriteMarker

◆ JpegWriteScanlines()

int BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.JpegWriteScanlines ( byte  scanlines[][],
int  num_lines 
)
inline

Write some scanlines of data to the JPEG compressor.

Parameters
scanlinesThe array of scanlines.
num_linesThe number of scanlines for writing.
Returns
The return value will be the number of lines actually written.
This should be less than the supplied num_lines only in case that the data destination module has requested suspension of the compressor, or if more than image_height scanlines are passed in.

We warn about excess calls to jpeg_write_scanlines() since this likely signals an application programmer error. However, excess scanlines passed in the last valid call are "silently" ignored, so that the application need not adjust num_lines for end-of-image when using a multiple-scanline buffer.

Compression details

◆ JpegWriteTables()

void BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.JpegWriteTables ( )
inline

Alternate compression function: just write an abbreviated table file.

Before calling this, all parameters and a data destination must be set up.

To produce a pair of files containing abbreviated tables and abbreviated image data, one would proceed as follows:

Initialize JPEG object
Set JPEG parameters
Set destination to table file
jpeg_write_tables();
Set destination to image file
jpeg_start_compress(false);
Write data...
jpeg_finish_compress();

jpeg_write_tables has the side effect of marking all tables written (same as jpeg_suppress_tables(true)). Thus a subsequent jpeg_start_compress will not re-emit the tables unless it is passed write_all_tables=true.

◆ OptimizeCoding

bool BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.OptimizeCoding
getset

Gets or sets a value indicating a way of using Huffman coding tables.

When this is true, you need not supply Huffman tables at all, and any you do supply will be overwritten.

true causes the compressor to compute optimal Huffman coding tables for the image. This requires an extra pass over the data and therefore costs a good deal of space and time. The default is false, which tells the compressor to use the supplied or default Huffman tables. In most cases optimal tables save only a few percent of file size compared to the default tables.

Compression parameter selection

◆ RestartInRows

int BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.RestartInRows
getset

Gets or sets the interval in MCU rows.

Default value: 0
If Restart_in_rows is not 0, then JpegCompressStruct.RestartInterval is set after the image width in MCUs is computed.
One restart marker per MCU row is often a good choice. The overhead of restart markers is higher in grayscale JPEG files than in color files, and MUCH higher in progressive JPEGs. If you use restarts, you may want to use larger intervals in those cases.

The restart interval in MCU rows.

See also
JpegCompressStruct.RestartInterval

Compression parameter selection

◆ Write_Adobe_marker

bool BitMiracle.LibJpeg.Classic.JpegCompressStruct.Write_Adobe_marker
getset

Gets or sets a value indicating whether to emit Adobe APP14 marker.

JpegCompressStruct.JpegSetDefaults and JpegCompressStruct.JpegSetColorspace set this true if JPEG color space RGB, CMYK, or YCCK is selected, otherwise false. It is generally a bad idea to set both JpegCompressStruct.Write_JFIF_header and JpegCompressStruct.Write_Adobe_marker. In fact, you probably shouldn't change the default settings at all - the default behavior ensures that the JPEG file's color space can be recognized by the decoder.

If true an Adobe APP14 marker is emitted; false, otherwise.

Compression parameter selection
